rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Isolation, origin and metabolism of neutral 15-alpha-hydroxysteroids in human pregnancy
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Labeled 15-alpha-hydroxysteroids were prepared microbiologically. Three neutral l5-alpha-hydroxylated steroids, namely, l5-alpha-hydroxyprogesterone (ISP), 15-alpha-hydroxyandrostenedione and 15-alpha-hydroxytestosterone were isolated from human late pregnancy urine. Among a large number of subjects examined, 15P could be detected only in the urine of subjects in the second and third trimester of pregnancy and it was not found in the urine of non-pregnant females and newborn infants. In two studies, 3H-progesterone was introduced into the peritoneal cavity of the human fetus at the time of amniocentesis and simultaneously 14C-progesterone was injected in the maternal compartment. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The growth characteristics of glioblastoma multiforme in the anterior chamber of the guinea pig eye
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Human glioblastoma multiforme in serial subculture in the anterior chamber of the guinea pig eye has been studied over a four-year interval to assess the stability of the tumor cell population and post response as an index of the suitability of this model in determining glioblastoma growth parameters including cell generation times. Tumor histology and growth pattern remained essentially unchanged, although a progressive loss of the striking host eosinophile response to the first generation tumors occurred in subsequent intraocular generations. The transplants were able to induce new vessel formation even in such avascular structures as the cornea. Spontaneous intratumor hemorrhages were characteristically seen. Radioautography with tritiated thymidine showed labeling of all nuclear types, though most commonly medium sized moderately vesicular nuclei. Demonstration of labeled mitosis indicated an average tumor cell generation time of 7 ± 0.5 days and a calculated DNA synthesis time of 7.5 ± 0.5 hours.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurology and Neurosurgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Adrenergic mechanisms in cardiac ischemic responses and in the action of antianginal drugs
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The cardiovascular changes (blood pressure and electrocardiograms) following lateral hypothalamic stimulation were studied in anesthetized rhesus monkeys. It was observed that central stimulation can induce striking adrenergic cardiovascular changes, culminating in demonstrable post-mortem myocardial necrosis. In both normal and coronary-ligated anesthetized open-chest dogs, hypothalamic: stimulation leads to coronary vasodilatation followed by vasoconstriction, associated with increased pressor responses and heart contractions, and arrhythmias; prior nitroglycerin and iproveratril administrations reduce: or prevent these changes. In coronary-ligated dogs both agents antagonize post-occlusion arrhythmias and the deleterious effects of adrenergic excitation (coronary vasoconstriction and arrhythmias) induced by noradrenaline and adrenaline. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pharmacology and Therapeutics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Nucleotide metabolism in Ehrlich ascites cells
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Studies have shown that about 95 per cent of the radioactivity incorporated from glucose-U-14C into RNA nucleotides is found in the ribose moiety of each nucleotide. The radiospecific activity of the ribose moieties of guanine and uracil were the highest; that of adenine was somewhat lower, while the specific activity of the ribose of cytosine was about ten times lower than the above three. It has been shown that the specific activities of the various nucleotides of RNA are a reflection of the labelling of the corresponding nucleotides in the acid-soluble fraction. These results are discussed in relation to the comparative utilization of purine and pyrimidine bases by radioactive ribose-phosphate for the formation of the labelled nucleotides of RNA.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: High resolution studies of short-lived nuclear isomers
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A versatile apparatus for studying short-lived nuclear isomers has been constructed. Using high resolution semi-conductor gamma-ray and conversion electron detectors, detailed studies of short-lived isomeric activities were undertaken. Improved data were obtained concerning a 90 micro-seconds isomer previously assigned to 121I . New information includes multipolarity determinations, relative intensity measurements, a revised assignment (to 122I), improved energy measurements, and the detection of at 1east one new transition (51.9 keV) and possibly two others. A new 293 micro-seconds M2 isomeric transition of 117 keV energy was assigned to 190Ir. New isomeric transitions, 166.5 keV (E2) and 47 keV (M2, or possib1y E2), were found in 189Pt (149 micro-seconds) and 191pt (100 micro-seconds), respectively; and two longer-lived transitions, 319.9 keV and 205 keV, were attributed to the decays of 189m-Au (5.0m) and 190m2-Ir (3.5 h), respectively. Tentative decay schemes are proposed which include these isomeric transitions.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Gamma-aminobutyric acid, other amino acids and electrolytes in relation to physiological and metabolic activities of brain
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The uptake of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) by brain slices from a balanced saline medium was found to be maximal with 3.6 millimolar potassium in the medium and was decreased by omission of potassium or calcium or by increasing the potassium concentration. No marked effects of GABA on potassium-stimulated oxygen uptake or on electrolyte accumulation or binding were found. Intraperitoneally-administered large volumes of hyperosmotic solutions of amine acids, sucrose or succinate delayed or protected against convulsions induced in rats by high oxygen pressure, picrotoxin or pentylenetetrazol. The effect was found to be associated with increased serum osmolarity and consequent dehydration of the brain. Labelled amino acids and other substances were collected from small areas of the exposed cerebral cortex of animals after subcutaneous injection of or perfusion of the brain with labelled glucose solution. No evidence for the presence of appreciable amounts of gamma-amino- beta-hydroxybutyric acid in rat brain could be obtained; beta-alanine was shown to be definitely present.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Esterification in rat adipose tissue
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The effect of 48-hour fasting on the in vivo esterification of fatty acids by rat epididymal adipose tissue was investigated. Fasting diminished the incorporation of radioactively labeled glucose and palmitate into intact adipose tissue lipids. This effect was not altered by the addition of insulin to the incubation medium. The decrease in esterification of labeled palmitate could also be detected in free adipocyte preparations and adipose tissue homogenates, incubated under optimal conditions, although to a lesser extent than in intact tissue. The following enzymes involved in esterification of fatty acids by adipose tissue were characterized and optimal conditions for the determination of their activity established: coenzyme A ligase (AMP), acyl-CoA: L-glycerol-3-phosphate acyltransferase, acyl-CoA deacylase, L-a-phosphatidate phosphohydrolase and acyl-CoA: diglyceride acyltransferase. The activities of these enzymes tested under optimal conditions were not altered by 48 hour fasting. Fatty acyl-CoA deacylase activity on the other hand was significantly decreased in the adipose tissue of the 48-hour fasted rat. The possibility is discussed that accumulation of long chain fatty acyl-CoA causes the decrease observed in esterification by the adipose tissue from fasted rats.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Amino acid movements in mouse pancreas
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Total movement of amino acids is the sum of simple diffusion, active transport, and exchange diffusion. Various aspects of the latter two processes have been investigated in mouse pancreas in vitro. (1) The uptake of amino-isobutyric acid and L-lysine over a wide range of concentrations may be explained in terms of one transport site, whereas kinetic analysis of L-tryptophan uptake suggests that at least two sites are involved. In addition to competition among neutral amino acids during transport, there is also competition between neutral and basic amino acids. Uptakes of ail the amino acids are inhibited by 0.1 mM 2, 4-dinitrophenol to about the same extent. The uptake of several neutral amino acids is scarcely sensitive to pH, white the uptake of L-lysine (basic) is significantly decreased at low pH. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Chemical and immunological investigations on enterococci
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Serological and chemical methods were used to study the antigenic constituents of enterococci. Lancefield and Fuller extracts of eight enterococcus strains, representing four species, were investigated in double diffusion in agar for antigenic pattern and relationship. Cell fractions of S. faecalis were examined for antigenic components by latex agglutination, passive hem agglutination and double diffusion. A group specific antigen was demonstrated in a cytoplasmic fraction. The isolated and partially purified antigen was analyzed chromatographically and electrophoretically. Cell wall components of representative strains were isolated by different methods and analyzed serologically and by paper and thin layer chromatography. Hexosamine, D(+) glucose and L(+) rhamnose were identified. The amino acid composition varied but DL alpha alanine was consistently present. A peptide consisting of seven amino acids was demonstrated. Immunoelectrophoretic analysis of such extracts appeared promising. Separation of components by gel filtration was unsuccessful. The G+C percentage composition of the strains was determined in cesium chloride density gradient.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Microbiology and Immunology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Histochemistry of the lung
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: On the basis of this investigation we made the following observations: 1. The alveolar cell is the metabolically most active cell of the interalveolar septum but the Clara cell is the metabolically most active cell of the peripheral airway system. The Clara cell contains relatively large amounts of firmly bound choline-base phospholipids. The alveolar cell also contains choline-base phospholipids but these are present in a free or loosely-bound form. 2. The oxidative enzyme pattern is the same in serous and mucous cells of the tracheobronchial glands. Oncocytes in tracheobronchial glands show stronger enzymatic reactions than serous and mucous cells. 3. The enzymes of the glycolytic scheme, Krebs cycle and hexose monophosphate shunt are functional in the urethane induced pulmonary adenoma. 4. The histochemical pattern of the free macrophages around the urethane adenomas and those induced by the intratracheal injection of iron is different from that of the tumour cell or alveolar cell.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pathology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect of cortisone on hexosamine and mucopolysaccharide metabolism
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Radioautographic studies indicated that the synthesis of sulfated mucopolysaccharides (MPS) in cartilage, skin, aorta and liver was decreased in rats treated with relatively large doses of cortisone. Chemical analyses showed that the hexosamine and hexuronic acid content of aorta and skin was decreased as was also the glucosamine content of liver in the treated animals. The activity of fructose-6-p-D-glutamine amidotransferase was decreased in supernatants from the liver homogenates of rats treated with cortisone for three days or longer. Similarly, the amidotransferase activity was decreased on addition of the soluble hydrocortisone succinate to normal liver supernatants, although the two effects may have different mechanisms of action. Studies with glucosamine-14C indicated that cortisone treatment caused no additional block in the hexosamine pathway. Thus, one way by which cortisone exerts its influence on MPS metabolism is by inhibiting the first step of the hexosamine biosynthetic pathway.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Chains of particles in shear flow
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Based on the creeping motion and lubrication equations, a theory for the behaviour of a straight chain consisting of a number of rigid spheres in shear flow was developed. When the spheres are in contact with one another, the chain should behave like a single rigid rod; quantitative confirmation was provided at low velocity gradients by experiments with chains of spheres formed in an electric field. At high gradients the chains broke. The periodic stretching of chains with non-zero gap width was in qualitative agreement with the theory. Chains of spheres held together by liquid menisci behaved like flexible threads and formed disordered aggregates at high velocity gradients. Aggregates of dises (rouleaux) behaved like deformable rods and were easily broken as the discs slid apart. Fore-aft symmetrical chains of non-uniform spheres and symmetrical but non-linear aggregates of spheres and aggregates of rods were also studied.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The formation and metabolism of steroid hormones in human fetus and placenta
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In the present studies, two previable human fetuses at mid-pregnancy were perfused with L-14-C-acetate and 7-alpha-3H-cholesterol. Cholesterol synthesis from L-14-C-acetate was demonstrated in the fetal adrenals and liver. Minute amounts of pregnenolone and 17-alpha-hydroxy-pregnenolone were isolated from the adrenals of one perfusion study, suggesting that neither acetate nor cholesterol serves as an efficient precursor for the formation of neutral steroids in the human fetus. Under identical experimental conditions, 7-alpha-3H-cholesterol sulfate was perfused in a previable human fetus and it was not metabolized by any of the tissues analysed, indicating that the human fetus at midterm does not seem to utilize cholesterol sulfate to any appreciable extent in the biosynthesis of neutral steroid sulfates.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Peptides of the neurohypophysis
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Acetone powder of pig posterior pituitary tissue was used as starting material for isolation of peptides. Extraction of peptides was effected by percolation with a d1scontinous gradient of alcohol, acetic acid and water. Peptides in the percolates were fractionated by methods of gel filtration on Sephadex columns and ion-exchange chromatography on DEAE- and CM-Cellulose. Two major polypeptides, designated P-64 and P-32, were isolated in a highly purified state. Their molecular weights were estimated to be about 9,000. Their amino acid compositions were marked by high contents of cystine and glyc1ne but no histidine and tryptophan was found. The purified polypeptides were found to be devoid of oxytocic, pressor and fat-mobilizing activities. Both polypeptides bind lysine vasopressin. The amino acid sequences of some tryptic peptides resulted from polypeptide P-64 have also been worked out.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The relative basicities of some group IV ethers
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Equilibrium constants, in the range 10 to 35°, for the formation of iodine complexes with [(CH3)3Ge]2O, (CH3)3GeOCH3, (CH3)3COCH3, (CH3)3SiOCH3, (n-C3H7)2O, (CH3)3COC2H5, (CH3)3SiOC2H5, [(CH3)3C]20, and [(CH3)3Si]2O were measured spectrophotometrically, and the corresponding enthalpy, free energy, and entropy changes were determined. The results show that basicities of these ethers decrease in the order listed. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A quantitative study of retrograde changes in the magnocellular nuclei of the human hypothalamus following hypophysectomy
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The topography of the human magnocellular nuclei has been redefined and normal values have been attributed for the frequency, density and spatial distribution of their neuron populations. Retrograde fallout after hypophysectomy occurs exponentially, leveling off after one year. Because of the exponential nature of neuron fallout, the time required for maximal loss probably has been grossly underestimated in many localization studies employing the method. In man approximately 80 percent of neurons in both the supraoptic and paraveatricu1ar nuclei project to the neurohypophysial posterior lobe. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Neurology and Neurosurgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Production of complement: cellular studies
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Production of complement was investigated using a modification of Jerne's plaque technique. Single cells and c1umps of cells present in normal guinea pig peritoneal exudate, similar to macrophages in appearance, produced plaques when incubated with sensitized sheep erythrocytes (EA) and guinea pig serum lacking the first component of complement (R1). Occasionally similar c1umps of cells produced plaques with EA and serum lacking the fourth component of complement (R4). Optimal plaque formation occurred when R1 or R4 was present at the start of incubation. Plaque formation was inhibited by KCN and dinitrophenol. No plaques were produced by spleen cells. Bone marrow cells produced plaques with both non-sensitized and sensitized erythrocytes only after prolonged incubation. Bone marrow and spleen cells produced plaques when incubated with nonsensitized erythrocytes and cobra venom. The lysis of red blood cells by cobra venom and guinea pig serum was investigated. Other possibly useful methods to detect the production of complement by single cells were examined.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Microbiology and Immunology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A temperate bacteriophage of Clostridium perfringens
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A temperate bacteriophage was isolated from a lysogenic strain of Clostridium perfringens. This strain was inducible by ultraviolet light and differed from the phage indicator strain by the absence of a haemolysin and pathogenicity for guinea pigs. Preliminary experiments did not reveal a phage-haemolysin relationship. One-step growth curves conducted in broth containing a reducing agent revealed latent and release periods of 45 minutes each. Phage yields were variable but, in general, quite low. Plaques produced on solid medium were small and possessed turbid centers. Lysogenization of the indicator strain occurred. The phage had a polyhedral head 80 x 70 mu and a striated tail 200 mu long as determined by electron microscopy. Experiments involving temperature, ultraviolet light and pH stability of the phage as well as adsorption experiments were performed. The phage nucleic acid, as determined by the diphenylamine reaction, acridine orange staining and sensitivity of phage multiplication to mitomycin C, was deoxyribonucleic acid.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Microbiology and Immunology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Solutions of the Bethe-Salpeter equation by a variational method
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A variational principle for the pion-nucleon phase-shifts is derived. It is based on the Bethe-Salpeter equation with nucleon exchange as the interaction kernel. The details of a procedure for carrying out the implied calculation are presented. The calculation is reduced to solving sets of linear equations.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies on water soluble rat brain antigens
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Antisera were produced in rabbits with saline extracts of homogenized rat brain and used to detect twelve antigens in similar extracts of the brain. Nine of the antigens were species-specific and could be detected in extracts of rat liver, kidney, testis, and adrenal. One was organ specific and was shared with human, bovine, guinea-pig, and rabbit brain. Another minor organ-specific antigen was found in human and guinea-pig brain extracts. A major antigen of the rat brain extracts appeared to be restricted to both the brain and the species. Two minor antigens also showed similar specificity. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The role of sulfate conjugates in the formation of adrenal steroids
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Tritiated pregnenolone and pregnenolone sulfate were incubated with homogenates of normal human adrenal and adrenal tumor tissue. In a 30 min incubation with normal adrenal tissue, pregnenolone was shown to be converted to pregnenolone sulfate, 17-alpha-hydroxypregnenolone sulfate, pregnenetriol sulfate, dehydroisoandrosterone sulfate, and pregnenetriol. Under the same conditions, 3H-pregnenolone sulfate was not converted to any detectable metabolites and 63 per cent of the substrate was recovered. It was concluded that the formation of the sulfates occurred primarily through the unconjugated intermediates rather than through the further metabolism of the intact sulfates. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Chemical synthesis and physiological properties of acetyl-l-carnitylcholine
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Acetyl-I-camitylcholine is both a carnitine and a choline ester, an isomer of succinylcholine and it contains two molecules of acetylcholine in its structure. It has been suggested that acetyl-I-camitylcholine could play an important role in nerve metabolism. In order to verify the hypothesis, this compound was chemically synthesized and its pharmacodynamic properties were compared with acetylcholine. Acetyl-I-carnitylcholine was labile to alkali treatment, hydrolyzed by true cholinesterase, and had an equipotent molar ratio of two when compared to acetylcholine on five different pharmacological test preparations. Its acetylcholine-like activity was potentiated by eserine and blocked by d-Tubocurarine and atropine. I-Carnitylcholine, a possible hydrolysis product of acetyl-I-carnitylcholine was found to be a potent neuromuscular blocker on the rat phrenic nerve-diaphragm preparation when compared to succinylcholine, acetyl-I-camitylcholine and acetylcholine. Paper and thin-layer chromatographic techniques were used to identify acetylcholine and acetyl-I-carnitylcholine in rat brain extracts.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Heterologous anti-lymphocyte serum and plasma
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Heterologous anti-lymphocyte serum (ALS) and plasma (ALP) are potent immuno-suppressive agents. The findings recorded in this thesis relate to their use and mode of action in thymectomized, sham-thymectomized and non-thymectomized rats and mice. No method is at present available for the in vitro standardization of ALP in terms of immuno-suppressive potency. Potency cannot be related to either, agglutinating and cytotoxic antibody titres directed against lymphocytes or to the ability of ALP to depress lymphocyte counts. The latter property of ALP has been found to be largely dependent on normal adrenal function in the recipient. The ability of ALS to prolong allograft survival times can be significantly improved if the recipient is thymectomized prior to the administration of serum and grafting performed after the completion of the course of ALS. An additional finding is that rats thymectomized in adult life show a progressive decline in immunological competence with the passage of time.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Surgery

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Further characterization of a streptococcal nephritogenic agent
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Additional studies were undertaken on the nature of a nephritogenic agent found in the culture filtrates of certain group A streptococci. A commercially available dehydrated medium proved satisfactory for the production of the active material. Gel filtration was used to divide crude extracts, prepared from the diffusible portion of culture filtrates, into two major fractions. One of these, representing the higher molecular weight components, contained most of the nephritogenic activity as evidenced by the development of hypertension and acute glomerulonephritis in rabbits injected with the fraction. Physical and chemicals studies indicated that the active fraction consisted of at least four peptide components separable by high-voltage electrophoresis on paper. Automatic amino acid analysis of an acid hydrolysate of this fraction revealed 17 different amino acids. Carbohydrate was not detected by anthrone and orcinol tests. No relationship between this streptococcal nephritogenic agent and other streptococcal constituents which have been implicated in nephritis was established.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Microbiology and Immunology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Growth hormone and protein synthesis
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The diaphragm of the hypophysectomized rat was utilized in studies designed to further clarify the mode of action of growth hormone. The experiments indicate that bovine growth hormone (BGH) does not stimulate the intracellular accumulation of leucine or tyrosine while stimulating incorporation of these amino acids. After 60 min, BGH in vitro stimulates amino acid incorporation by cell debris, microsomes, and soluble protein. However, no effect is seen when subcellular particles are exposed to BGH directly. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Experimental Medicine
